newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK activists defy Taiwan warning on islands.
newsitem.headline: HK activists defy Taiwan warning on islands.

text.p: Hong Kong activists, ignoring a warning from Taiwan, on Saturday prepared to travel to a cluster of disputed islands in the East China Sea to challenge Japan's claim of sovereignty.
The 80 activists planned to fly to Taiwan later in the day and join demonstrators preparing to sail on Monday morning to the islands, which are claimed by Beijing, Taipei and Tokyo.
Taiwan hinted on Friday it might halt the protest voyage, saying the private flotilla could be illegal.

"As a government for Chinese people, not only it (Taiwan government) does not help Chinese to return to their soil, but instead it intimidates Chinese people from going there," Democratic Party legislator Albert Chan told reporters.

Governor Chris Patten on Friday urged the activists to be careful. "I do hope they will do everything possible not to put themselves or others in any physical danger, however strongly they feel about the issue in question," he said.

Patten also offered condolences to the family of activist David Chan, who drowned near the disputed isles last week after jumping off a ship to protest Japan's soverignty claim. His funeral was to be held on Saturday and Sunday.

Japan has claimed the potentially resource-rich islands, which it calls the Senkakus, since 1895 and refuses to admit that their sovereignty is open to discussion. China, which calls the islands the Diaoyus, has claimed them for centuries.
